thread.title: People are blaming Leonardo DiCaprio for the epic Oscars mistake - here's proof he didn't 'sabotage' the awards
thread.title_full: People are blaming Leonardo DiCaprio for the epic Oscars mistake - here's proof he didn't 'sabotage' the awards

author: Nicola Oakley
title: People are blaming Leonardo DiCaprio for the epic Oscars mistake - here's proof he didn't 'sabotage' the awards
text:
Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The showbiz world is still recovering from the biggest mistake in Oscars history last night - after the wrong movie was named Best Picture. 
La La Land was read out as the winner by Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, but once the cast had assembled on the stage it was revealed that Moonlight had actually won (and there were a lot of red faces). 
It's led many people to question today how such a huge mix-up could have happened - and people are blaming Leonardo DiCaprio. 
Poor Leo, what's he done to deserve this? 
It all came about because he had presented the award for Best Actress in a Leading Role and handed winner Emma Stone her Oscar. Is this the envelope that caused the mix-up? Well, no (Photo: Getty) 
As we now know, the confusion at the end of the awards show all came about because Warren Beatty was given the wrong card - which announced Emma Stone in La La Land as Best Actress. 
So, naturally, people thought that the card Leo was holding earlier in the night somehow wound its way back on to the stage again. Read More The way Andrew Garfield looked at ex-girlfriend Emma Stone during her Oscars speech is breaking hearts 
They started blaming him for keeping hold of the card and "putting it down somewhere" where it was later picked up mistakenly and used for the Best Picture announcement. 
Some even accused him of sabotaging the awards show because of his long history of, well, not winning. 
But we want to clear Leo's name once and for all. Here's why Leo isn't to blame 
There is video evidence of Emma Stone holding the red card as she came off the stage at the awards. Read More 
In the clip, Leonardo DiCaprio guides her through a crowd of photographers and she can clearly be seen holding the red envelope. See! Leo gave the card to Emma straight away (Photo: Getty) 
She also told reporters she didn't let go of the card the whole evening. 
Beatty explained to the audience how the card he had opened said "Emma Stone, La La Land", which is why he hesitated after he opened the envelope. 
Reports claimed that two cards are made for each awards category and two workers stand at either side of the stage alternating between who has the responsibility of handing them out. 
So it's entirely possible there were two cards and they got mixed up. (Photo: AFP) 
In a statement, the accountancy firm responsible for handing out envelopes apologised to everyone affected by the embarrassing blunder. 
A spokesperson PricewaterhouseCoopers said: "We sincerely apologize to Moonlight, La La Land, Warren Beatty, Faye Dunaway, and Oscar viewers for the error that was made during the award announcement for best picture," 
"The presenters had mistakenly been given the wrong category envelope and when discovered, was immediately corrected. We are currently investigating how this could have happened, and deeply regret that this occurred." The cast of "Moonlight" and ""La La Land" appear on stage (Photo: AFP) 
PWC concluded by thanking the nominees, the Academy, ABC, the network that aired the show, and the Oscars host Jimmy Kimmel for how they reacted. 
"We appreciate the grace with which the nominees, the Academy, ABC, and Jimmy Kimmel handled the situation." Read More
